channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: What's up with weird Covid-19 symptoms?
item.description: The Coronavirus Podcast - Scientific studies have reported some unusual symptoms from Covid-19 - so what are they?

item.title: Covid-19: What happened on 4 May
item.description: For the first time in weeks, there are no new reported cases of Covid-19 in New Zealand. Meanwhile, cases globally have surpassed 3.5 million.

item.title: Wave warning system introduced after huge swell hit Wellington
item.description: Huge swells heading for Wellington were known about for two days before they hit last month, but residents were not told. Now, a warning system is in place.

item.title: NZers take haircuts into own hands in lockdown
item.description: Supermarkets are reporting a 140 percent jump in hair dyes, and hair clipper sales have doubled, as New Zealanders take their hair into their own hands during lockdown.

item.title: Covid-19: New Zealand government to grant itself visa law powers for 12 months
item.description: The government is temporarily amending immigration law to make it more flexible and responsive to challenges posed by Covid-19.

item.title: Rain welcome, but no relief to dry conditions
item.description: Aucklanders are being warned a weekend of extremely wet weather hasn't brought the city any closer to seeing the end of what is a severe drought.

item.title: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern to join Australia Cabinet meeting to discuss trans-Tasman bubble
item.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern will join Australia's Cabinet meeting tomorrow via video link to discuss the possibility of a trans-Tasman bubble.

item.title: Without Keytruda, 30 deaths a week in NZ from cancer - Lung Foundation
item.description: Pharmac's decision to backtrack on funding Keytruda is a major blow for equality in New Zealand's health system, a leading oncologist says.

item.title: Police reveal name of woman killed in Auckland
item.description: Police have released the name of the woman who died after an explosion in Mt Roskill on Friday.

item.title: Budgeting services request more funding to handle unemployment increase
item.description: Budgeting services are calling for a doubling of their funding to help deal with an expected tidal wave of people seeking help.

item.title: Invercargill man denied ambulance despite being incapacitated
item.description: A Southlander is upset St John's communications staff refused to send an ambulance to his father, who had collapsed and was unable to move due to pain.

item.title: Live: Covid-19 updates from New Zealand and around the world on 4 May
item.description: Today, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said she wanted low numbers of cases to continue to be sure they reflect alert level 3. Look back at RNZ's live updates here.

item.title: Taranaki tourism operators welcome slight upturn after lockdown
item.description: Accommodation providers in Taranaki are seeing signs that domestic tourism could help them recover from the devastation caused by the Covid-19 coronavirus.

item.title: Queenstown flights: Petition, mayor's letter urges return of air services
item.description: With a petition gaining thousands of signatures, a campaign to reopen Queenstown to aviation is gaining support.

item.title: Lockdown social cohesion likely to fall as 'acute' phase ends - scientists
item.description: The sense of national unity felt during the lockdown may disappear as social isolation and economic costs hit home, a report by leading social scientists warns.

item.title: Gun owners in court over government compensation for ammunition
item.description: Gun owners who were forced to hand in ammunition say they have been given a raw deal.

item.title: Director-General of Health Ashley Bloomfield says no new cases of Covid-19 is 'encouraging'
item.description: There are no new cases or deaths from Covid-19 reported in New Zealand today, but the country will not know until later this week if level 3 has led to increased spread.

item.title: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern: A few letting the side down over level 3 breaches
item.description: Jacinda Ardern says she doesn't want to see the "team of 5 million" punished for the activities of a few, after breaches of social distancing rules over the weekend.
